expanded_description: A system of linear inequalities consists of two or more inequalities that must be satisfied simultaneously. The solution is the region of the coordinate plane where all inequalities overlap—the intersection of their individual solution sets. Graphing these systems visually represents feasible regions and is the foundation for linear programming and optimization problems.

core_concept.principle: To graph a system of linear inequalities: (1) Graph each inequality separately on the same coordinate plane, using the correct line style (solid or dashed) and shading for each. (2) The solution to the system is the region where the shading overlaps—the area that satisfies all inequalities. (3) If there is no overlap, the system has no solution.
core_concept.explanation: Think of each inequality as a colored filter. Alone, each filter lets light through a certain region. When you stack the filters, only the areas where all filters are transparent let light through—that's your solution region. If no area is common to all filters, no light gets through (no solution).

image.alt: Three inequalities graphed separately, then combined showing overlapping region
image.caption: Figure 8.4.1: Graphing a system of inequalities - the solution is the overlapping region.

sections.introduction: Before tackling systems, let's quickly review how to graph a single inequality correctly.

key_concept.definition:
Remember the steps for graphing a single inequality:
1. Graph the boundary line (solid for ≤ or ≥, dashed for < or >).
2. Choose a test point (usually (0,0) if not on the line).
3. Shade the side where the test point makes the inequality true.
key_concept.context: Accuracy in graphing each individual inequality is essential for correctly identifying the overlapping region.

image.alt: Examples of correctly graphed single inequalities
image.caption: Figure 8.4.3: Single inequality examples.

worked_examples.title: Quick Graphing Practice
worked_examples.problem:
Graph each inequality on a separate coordinate plane (just for review):
a) $y > 2x - 1$
b) $3x + 2y \leq 12$

step_by_step.explanation: Boundary: $y = 2x - 1$ (dashed). Test (0,0): $0 > -1$ true, shade side with origin. Also $>$ means shade above.
Boundary: $3x + 2y = 12$ (solid). Intercepts (0,6) and (4,0). Test (0,0): $0 \leq 12$ true, shade side with origin.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Review of correct graphing technique for single inequalities.

image.alt: Summary of single inequality graphing review
image.caption: Figure 8.4.7: Review summary.

sections.introduction: When graphing two inequalities, we shade each one and look for the overlap.

introduction_image.alt: Two inequalities graphed with overlapping region
introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.4.8: Graphing a system of two inequalities.

key_concept.definition: To graph a system of two inequalities, graph both on the same coordinate plane. Use different shading patterns or colors to distinguish them. The solution region is where the shadings overlap. This region represents all points that satisfy both inequalities.
key_concept.context: The overlapping region may be bounded (a polygon) or unbounded (extending infinitely).

image.alt: Example: y > x and y ≤ -x + 4 with overlap shown
image.caption: Figure 8.4.9: Two-inequality system example.

worked_examples.title: Graphing a System of Two Inequalities

image.alt: Systems of two inequalities to graph
image.caption: Figure 8.4.10: Graph each system.

worked_examples.problem:
Graph each system of inequalities and identify the solution region:
a) $\begin{cases} y > x - 2 \\ y \leq -x + 4 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 2x + y \geq 4 \\ x - y < 3 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: Boundary $y = x - 2$ (dashed). Test (0,0): $0 > -2$ true, shade side with origin. Also $>$ means shade above.
Boundary $y = -x + 4$ (solid). Test (0,0): $0 \leq 4$ true, shade side with origin. $\leq$ means shade below.
The solution is where both shadings overlap—a triangular region.

image.caption: Figure 8.4.13: Solution region for system a.

step_by_step.explanation: Rewrite as $y \geq -2x + 4$ (solid). Test (0,0): $0 \geq 4$ false, shade opposite side from origin. $\geq$ means shade above.
Rewrite as $-y < -x + 3$ → $y > x - 3$ (dashed). Test (0,0): $0 > -3$ true, shade side with origin. $>$ means shade above.
The solution is the overlap—a region extending infinitely.

image.caption: Figure 8.4.16: Solution region for system b.

worked_examples.final_answer: Graphs as shown in figures, with solution regions identified.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Graph each inequality separately, then identify the overlapping region as the solution.

process_flow.description: Graph the first inequality with correct line style and shading.
process_flow.mechanism: Use boundary line and test point or above/below rule.

process_flow.description: Graph the second inequality on the same plane, using a different shading pattern.
The solution region is where the shadings intersect.
process_flow.mechanism: Look for area covered by both shading patterns.

sections.section_title: 8.4.3 Graphing Systems with Three or More Inequalities
sections.introduction: Systems can have more than two inequalities. The solution region is where all inequalities overlap.

key_concept.definition: For systems with three or more inequalities, the solution region is the intersection of all individual solution sets. This region is often a polygon (triangle, quadrilateral, etc.) bounded by the lines. The vertices of this polygon are intersection points of pairs of boundary lines.
key_concept.context: These systems model real-world situations with multiple constraints.

image.alt: Example: y ≥ 0, x ≥ 0, x + y ≤ 5 gives triangular region
image.caption: Figure 8.4.22: Three-inequality system example.

worked_examples.title: Graphing a Three-Inequality System
worked_examples.problem: Graph the system and identify the solution region: $\begin{cases} y \geq 0 \\ x \geq 0 \\ x + y \leq 5 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal line at $y=0$ (x-axis), solid. Shade above.
Vertical line at $x=0$ (y-axis), solid. Shade to the right.
Boundary $x + y = 5$ (solid). Intercepts (0,5) and (5,0). Test (0,0): $0 \leq 5$ true, shade side with origin (below the line).
The overlap is the triangle with vertices at (0,0), (5,0), and (0,5).

worked_examples.final_answer: Solution region is the triangle with vertices (0,0), (5,0), (0,5).
worked_examples.concept_applied: The intersection of all inequalities gives a bounded polygonal region.

worked_examples.title: System with Non-Negativity Constraints

image.alt: System with x ≥ 0, y ≥ 0, and other constraints
image.caption: Figure 8.4.28: Non-negativity constraints.

worked_examples.problem: Graph the system: $\begin{cases} x \geq 0 \\ y \geq 0 \\ 2x + y \leq 8 \\ x + 2y \leq 8 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: These restrict to first quadrant.
Boundary $2x + y = 8$ (solid). Intercepts (0,8) and (4,0). Shade toward origin.
Boundary $x + 2y = 8$ (solid). Intercepts (0,4) and (8,0). Shade toward origin.
The overlap is a quadrilateral with vertices at (0,0), (4,0), (0,4), and intersection of the two lines.

worked_examples.final_answer: Solution region is a quadrilateral with vertices (0,0), (4,0), (8/3,8/3), (0,4).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multiple constraints create polygonal feasible regions.

image.alt: Summary of graphing three or more inequalities
image.caption: Figure 8.4.33: Multiple inequality systems summary.

sections.introduction: Sometimes the inequalities have no common overlap—the system has no solution.

key_concept.definition: If the shaded regions of the inequalities do not overlap at all, the system has no solution. This happens when the conditions are contradictory, such as $y > x + 2$ and $y < x - 1$ (parallel boundaries with no overlap).
key_concept.context: Recognizing no-solution systems prevents wasting time searching for a feasible region.

image.alt: Example: y > x+2 and y < x-1 with no overlap
image.caption: Figure 8.4.35: No overlap means no solution.

worked_examples.title: Identifying No-Solution Systems

image.caption: Figure 8.4.36: Determine if each has a solution.

worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each system has a solution:
a) $\begin{cases} y > 2x + 1 \\ y < 2x - 3 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} y \geq -x + 4 \\ y \leq -x - 2 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} x + y \leq 5 \\ x + y \geq 6 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: Both have slope 2, intercepts 1 and -3. $y > 2x+1$ shades above, $y < 2x-3$ shades below. No overlap.
$y \geq -x+4$ shades above, $y \leq -x-2$ shades below. No overlap.

step_by_step.step: c) First shades below line $x+y=5$, second shades above $x+y=6$
step_by_step.explanation: These are parallel lines with no overlap between the regions.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) No solution, b) No solution, c) No solution
worked_examples.concept_applied: When shaded regions don't intersect, the system has no solution.

sections.introduction: The vertices (corner points) of the solution region are important for optimization problems.

introduction_image.alt: Solution region with corner points labeled
introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.4.38: Corner points of the feasible region.

key_concept.definition: Corner points are where boundary lines intersect. They are found by solving systems of equations formed by pairs of boundary lines. These points are crucial in linear programming because optimal solutions often occur at corners.
key_concept.context: Finding corner points prepares students for linear programming applications.

image.alt: Example: Find intersection of x+y=5 and x=0 gives (0,5)
image.caption: Figure 8.4.39: Finding corner points.

worked_examples.title: Finding Corner Points

image.alt: System with corner points to find
image.caption: Figure 8.4.40: Find all corner points of the solution region.

worked_examples.problem: For the system $\begin{cases} x \geq 0 \\ y \geq 0 \\ 2x + y \leq 8 \\ x + 2y \leq 8 \end{cases}$, find all corner points of the solution region.

step_by_step.explanation: Boundary lines: $x=0$, $y=0$, $2x+y=8$, $x+2y=8$
Solve system: $2x+y=8$, $x+2y=8$
step_by_step.calculation: Multiply second by 2: $2x+4y=16$, subtract first: $3y=8$ → $y=\frac{8}{3}$, then $x=8-2y=8-\frac{16}{3}=\frac{8}{3}$ → $(\frac{8}{3}, \frac{8}{3})$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Corner points are intersections of boundary lines that lie within the feasible region.

sections.section_title: 8.4.6 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when graphing systems of inequalities. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Shading different sides for different inequalities without clear distinction.
characteristics: Using same shading pattern for all inequalities

image.alt: Unclear shading vs clear overlapping shading
image.caption: Figure 8.4.42: Error - inconsistent shading.

examples.process: Error: Using only one color/direction for all inequalities
examples.explanation: Correct: Use different patterns or colors to distinguish inequalities

classifications.value: Overlooking constraints like $x \geq 0$ and $y \geq 0$ in real-world problems.
characteristics: Not restricting to first quadrant when context requires
classifications.behavior: Solution region too large, includes unrealistic points.

image.alt: Correct region with non-negativity vs incorrect without
image.caption: Figure 8.4.43: Error - forgetting non-negativity constraints.

examples.process: Error: In production problem, not including $x \geq 0$, $y \geq 0$
examples.explanation: Correct: Quantities can't be negative, so include these constraints

classifications.value: Choosing wrong region as the overlap.
characteristics: Not checking a test point in the claimed region

examples.process: Error: Shading the union of regions instead of intersection
examples.explanation: Correct: Solution is intersection, where ALL are true

worked_examples.title: Correcting System Graphing Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student graphed $\begin{cases} y \geq x \\ y \leq -x + 4 \end{cases}$ and shaded the region above both lines. Is this correct?

step_by_step.explanation: $y \geq x$ means shade above line $y=x$
$y \leq -x + 4$ means shade below line $y=-x+4$
step_by_step.calculation: Student shaded above both, which is wrong for second

step_by_step.explanation: The solution is the region that is above $y=x$ AND below $y=-x+4$
step_by_step.calculation: A triangular region between the lines

worked_examples.final_answer: Student shaded incorrectly for second inequality. Correct region is between the lines.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Each inequality must be shaded correctly; the solution is the intersection.

image.alt: Summary table of common system graphing errors and corrections
image.caption: Figure 8.4.46: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to graph a variety of systems of inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Graph each system of inequalities and identify the solution region:
1) $\begin{cases} y > 2x - 1 \\ y \leq -x + 3 \end{cases}$
2) $\begin{cases} x + y \geq 4 \\ x - y < 2 \end{cases}$
3) $\begin{cases} y \geq 0 \\ x \geq 0 \\ 2x + 3y \leq 12 \end{cases}$
4) $\begin{cases} y < 2x + 1 \\ y > 2x - 3 \end{cases}$ (special case)
5) $\begin{cases} x + y \leq 5 \\ x \geq 1 \\ y \geq 2 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: $y > 2x - 1$ (dashed, above), $y \leq -x + 3$ (solid, below)
$x + y \geq 4$ → $y \geq -x + 4$ (solid, above), $x - y < 2$ → $y > x - 2$ (dashed, above)
$y \geq 0$, $x \geq 0$ (first quadrant), $2x + 3y \leq 12$ (solid, below)
$y < 2x + 1$ (dashed, below), $y > 2x - 3$ (dashed, above) - these create a strip between parallel lines
$x \geq 1$, $y \geq 2$, $x + y \leq 5$ - bounded triangle

worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice graphing various systems and identifying solution regions.

summary: Graphing systems of linear inequalities involves plotting each inequality on the same coordinate plane and identifying the region where all inequalities are satisfied simultaneously. The solution region is the intersection of the individual solution sets. Use different shading patterns or colors to distinguish inequalities. The region may be bounded (a polygon) or unbounded, and its vertices (corner points) are found by solving pairs of boundary line equations. If the shaded regions do not overlap at all, the system has no solution—the conditions are contradictory. In real-world applications, non-negativity constraints ($x \geq 0$, $y \geq 0$) are common and restrict the region to the first quadrant. Mastering system graphing is essential for linear programming and optimization problems, where we find the best solution within a feasible region.
